name: Master Smiter: Paladin 16 / Champion of Torm 22 / Monk 2
author: magaiti

posts.author: magaiti

Aim of the build:
- Next to highest non-crit smite damage: 38x11 = 418
- Maxed Discipline, Taunt
- Blind fight
- Playability (Knockdown, good saves, decent AB, AC, HP values, intermediate skilldumps)

There are lots of smiting builds around, but I have found none with maxed non-crit Smite damage (good against undead bosses, for example), and I tried to make it as playable as possible.
It can also be done using Rogue or Harper Scout instead of Monk (HS variant should start with 12 INT and 17 CHA)

Build notes:
- Scimitar is chosen for Sword and Board playstyle, and wide crit range to maximize critical smite chance. If you want to beat specifically undead, a bludgeoning weapon might be a better choice (and IC feat can be dumped)
- Monk at level 22 is for leveling convenience only, it can be replaced with a Paladin level for little extra smite damage.
- Points in spellcraft, just so you can gain bonus from party member's bard song.
- Level 40 ability point should be placed according to equipment available. I expect to max out STR and CHA, and wear Monk's boots giving +3 DEX, so I can cap Dex AC bonus. Actually, Point into CON and Boots of Hardiness +3 may be a better choice, since your dodge bonus will be capped as long as you are hasted and have DS on.
- Luck of Heroes and Toughness are not essential, you can take Extend Spell.

Hail, magaiti!

Thanks for posting this build and keeping these halls alive. Now, as to the build itself, I would add many suggestions to improve the build, although you would give up a bit of saves. I'll suggest many alterations, mainly pre-epic, as post-epic pretty much all feats are GSs. OK, here we go!

1-Drop Luck of Heroes for Expertise, so you can use the Expertise / Taunt combo. I wouldn't say that your AB is decent, I would say it's average at best, being 37 and all, which would cap at 63 with capped STR and +20 enhancement (which Paladins can't reach on their own). In that sense, you can Taunt while in Expertise, gaining 5 AC for free. And it's always nice to have Taunt / Expertise / Power Attack, as these feats make you more versatile. You can fight DR with Divine Might / Taunt / Power Attack, you can drastically increase your AC with no AB penalty with Divine Shield / Taunt / Expertise, etc... This will require that you rework your stats, but it should be easy enough to do.

2- Start with STR 15, DEX 8, CON 8, Wis 14 INT 14 CHA 16. That will delay the first Great Smite feat, but you will end up with 18 STR (and +1 AB), 26 CHA and 86 more skill points which your build REALLY could use.

3- If you're going to use these three classes, why not go Paladin 29 / CoT 10 / Monk 1? That way you can do more Smite damage, have the same number of feats, but many more spells per day and are undispellable except for Mord's. You will lose +3 to all saves, but IMO it's a very interesting trade. Al level 16 with 14 Wisdom you have 3 lvl 1 spells, 3 lvl 2 spells, 1 lvl 3 spell and 1 lvl 4 spell. With 29 Pally levels, you'll have 4 lvl 1 spells, 4 lvl 2 spells, 3 lvl 3 spells, and 3 lvl 4 spells. The side effect that in the end won't matter is that you'll lose the Monk skill dump at lvl 22 (and deflect arrows which is useless), but with Expertise and Divine Shield, that will hardly be a problem.

Compared to your build, this one would have +1 AB and damage, +1 level count towards Smiting damage (+11 damage on smites, 22 on criticals), - 8 to all saves, -38 HP, Full Concentration, 40 Listen and 1 Open Locks (just so you can use thieves tools and take advantage of the Bard Song), +2 lvl 3 spells a day, +2 lvl 4 spells a day, +1 lvl 1 and +1 lvl 2 spells a day.

I would like to add that a MAXIMUM DC for a spell is 48 (for Implosion, which has an innate +3 to DC, cast by a 38 WISDOM Cleric with CAPPED WISDOM and ALL 3 SPELL FOCUS FEATS in Evocation). Now, arcane spells would have a MAX DC of 45. This build here has 40 FORT save, with Capped CHA, so with a Ring of Resistance +5, you'd already guarantee success against all arcane spells cast by even the most proficient mage with the best of gear. Most spells won't have such high DCs, so you don't need to have such high saves. It's surely nice, but Autofail is pretty much the only situation in which this build would fall to a spell, except in the very specific situation of a non-smitable dedicated caster followed by an unlucky roll. I would rather die in these situations and have the extra spells for all others. Basically, what I'm trying to say is that you sort of give up some things that are more or less in excess, although nice to have (KD, saves), to attain other much more useful things, such as spells per day, more smite damage, undispellability (which can be invaluable in many worlds).

Take it EZ!

Normally when I approach hostile spellcasters, I do so invisible and take them by surprise. Using consumables is very important in NWN so all my meleers have Invisibility potions. That way, you attack them first and with the damage (likely lots of criticals per round), they won't be able to fire off spells, which is kind of like a KD. But where I play, not many mobs have True Seeing, so that can be done. If where you play they normally have True Seeing, then KD becomes invaluable, but then again if KD immunities are available, it becomes useless, so I guess it all depends where you play. I normally just come in invisible and attack the caster with everything I have. If there is more than one caster, you will probably have to smite one and then go right after the other (or run like hell and come back later). Either way, that's why I don't consider KD essential. With my style, the casters normally go down before they can fire off a single spell.

posts.content:
Oh yes, a spellcaster that can be stalked by a mere fighter gulping invisibility potions? He must be too dumb to live.

On the server where I was playing (levelcap 20, russian PW "Gem of the North") mobs are spawned prebuffed, already with See Invisibility / True Sight, and all the defensive buffs, like Premonition, Improved Invisibility. They don't waste time buffing themselves and are ready to throw dispels, Mords, breaches, and all kinds of offensive spells on sight. Mobs are clever enough to follow their mates, so you cannot pull a single mob, unless others are blinded or something. Just bashing casters to prevent them from casting won't work, as they are buffed with haste, DR and miss chance spells, and have good concentration scores. KD on the other hand, checks their lowish Discipline, and shuts their casting down for an entire round.

Sounds pretty hardcore, and it is. KD was invaluable there, as well as BF. These times, I am playing on less hardcore PWs, but still think that it's better to be prepared.

I was thinking about tuning my smiter build for a particular rather hardcode PW, and ended up with pretty much your build, but i took both KD and Expertise,
at the cost of ImpCrit (can be taken later at epics instead of one of GS). Also 1 epic feat used for ESFiscipline, so I ended up with 8 GS feats, which is still pretty cool. But I guess there have already been such builds posted somewhere. So much for trying to be creative.

May I ask why did you max Listen instead of Spot in your build? CoT has spot as class skill.
